verb.description: To shut up or confine (a thing or person); to close off, to obstruct access to.
To cut (a person) off from the world, society, etc.; to seclude from. Now rare.

origin: Late Middle English (in an earlier sense). From classical Latin reclūdere to open, to open up, throw open, (later also) to shut or store away, to shut off (2nd cent. a.d.), in post-classical Latin also (in passive, recludi) to withdraw from the world as a recluse from re- + claudere to close.
